name: Real world problems with negative integers

skills.name: Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer
Carry out missing number addition problems involving negative integers
Carry out subtraction problems involving one negative integer
Carry out missing number subtraction problems involving negative integers

explanations.A: Not quite. I think you may have subtracted 15 from -20. But if the diver is ascending (coming up) they are not getting further below sea level, they are getting closer to the surface.
explanations.B: Be careful. I think you may have added 20 and 15. Think of below sea level as being negative. So the diver is at -20 and then comes up by 15 (add 15).
explanations.C: You can think of 20 feet below sea level as -20. If you ascend (come up) by 15, that's the same as adding 15. -20 + 15 = -5. The diver is 5 feet below sea level.
explanations.D: Almost! I think you have subtracted 15 from positive 20. Think of below sea level as being negative. So start at -20 and then ascend (come up) by 15. Will you have got above sea level?

explanations.A: Almost! I think you have subtracted 25 from positive 40. Think of below sea level as being negative. So start at -40 and then ascend (come up) by 25. Will you have got above sea level?
explanations.B: You can think of 40feet below sea level as -40. If you ascend (come up) by 25, that's the same as adding 25. -40 + 25 = -15. The diver is 15 feet below sea level.
explanations.C: Be careful. I think you may have added 40 and 25. Think of below sea level as being negative. So the diver is at -40 and then comes up by 25 (add 25).
explanations.D: Be careful. I think you may have subtracted 25 from -40 to get -65 (65 feet below sea level). But if the diver is ascending (coming up) they are not getting further below sea level, they are getting closer to the surface.

explanations.A: The difference between -14 and 44 is 58. You can think of this as 44 - -14 = 44+14 = 58.
explanations.B: I think you may have added -14 and 44 together. We want the amount of difference between -14 and 44. Think of the values on a number line each side of zero. What is the total distance between those values?
explanations.C: I think you may have added -14 and -44 together to get -58. But the roof elevation is positive. That is above ground level. You need to find the difference between -14 and 44. How might you do that? What do you add to -14 to get to 44?
explanations.D: I think you may have seen the difference between 14 and 44 is 30. But remember the 14 is negative. Think of the values on a number line -14 and 44. What is the total difference? You can think about it as going from -14 up to zero and then from zero to 44 to help break it down.

explanations.A: I think you may have added -12 and 62 together. We want the amount of difference between -12 and 62. Think of the values on a number line each side of zero. What is the total distance between those values?
explanations.B: I think you may have added -12 and -62 together to get -74. But the elevation of the roof is positive. That is above ground level. You need to find the difference between -12 and 62. How might you do that? What do you add to -12 to get to 62?
explanations.C: The difference between -12 and 62 is 74. You can think of this as 62 - -12 = 62+12 = 74.
explanations.D: I think you may have seen the difference between 12 and 62 is 50. But remember the 12 is negative. Think of the values on a number line -12 and 62. What is the total difference? You can think about it as going from -12 up to zero and then from zero to 62 to help break it down.

explanations.A: Not quite. Bryce has -$35 which means he has gone below zero. He actually owes the bank $35. So if he withdraws $35 then he will owe them even more (he will be at -$70). How can he get it back to zero from -35?
explanations.B: If Bryce is at -$35 then he deposits (adds) $35 to his account he will be at zero. He has cleared the negative balance. -35 + 35 = 0.
explanations.C: Bryce is already at -$35 so he owes the bank $35. If he withdraws $70 he will owe them even more, what does he need to do to get the balance back to zero so he doesn't owe anything?
explanations.D: Bryce is at -$35 so he owes the bank $35. If he deposits $70 he will go over zero as he'll be putting in more than he owes. What does he need to do to get the balance back to exactly zero?

explanations.A: Olivia is at -$55 so she owes the bank $55. If she deposits $110 she will go over zero as she'll be putting in more than she owes. What does she need to do to get the balance back to exactly zero?
explanations.B: Olivia is already at -$55 so she owes the bank $55. If she withdraws $110 she will owe them even more, what does she need to do to get the balance back to zero so she doesn't owe anything?
explanations.C: If Olivia is at -$55 then she deposits (adds) $55 to her account she will be at zero. She has cleared the negative balance. -55 + 55 = 0.
explanations.D: Not quite. Olivia has -$55 which means she has gone below zero. She actually owes the bank $55. So if she withdraws $55 then she will owe them even more (she will be at -$110). How can she get it back to zero from -55?

explanations.A: I think you may have found the difference between 38 and 17. But we need the difference between -38 and 17. It may help to think of the values on a number line. What is the gap between them? You could go from -38 to zero and then from zero to 17 to help break it down.
explanations.B: I think you may have found the difference between the two high temperatures. Make sure to read the question carefully, this asks for the difference in the two low temperatures.
explanations.D: I think you may have looked at the two bottom numbers in the table. Look at the table carefully, which is the lowest temperature for Phoenix and which is the lowest temperature for Arizona?

explanations.B: I think you may have found the difference between 27 and 14. But we need the difference between -27 and 14. It may help to think of the values on a number line. What is the gap between them? You could go from -27 to zero and then from zero to 14 to help break it down.
explanations.C: I think you may have looked at the two top numbers in the table. Look at the table carefully, which is the lowest temperature for Davenport and which is the lowest temperature for Newark?
explanations.D: I think you may have found the difference between the two high temperatures. Make sure to read the question carefully, this asks for the difference in the two low temperatures.

explanations.A: I think you may have found the difference between 38 and 92. But we need the difference between -38 and 92. It may help to think of the values on a number line. What is the gap between them? You could go from -38 to zero and then from zero to 92 to help break it down.
explanations.B: Low temperature for Anchorage is -38 and high temperature for Anchorage is 92. The difference between 92 and -38 is 130. 92 - -38 = 92+38 = 130.
explanations.C: I think you may have looked at the numbers in the first column. Read the question carefully. Which is the low temperature for Anchorage and which is the high temperature for Anchorage?
explanations.D: Almost! I think you have worked out the difference for Phoenix. Take another look at the question.

explanations.A: Almost! I think you have worked out the difference for Newark. Take another look at the question.
explanations.B: I think you may have looked at the numbers in the first column. Read the question carefully. Which is the low temperature for Davenport and which is the high temperature for Davenport?
explanations.C: Low temperature for Davenport is -27 and high temperature for Davenport is 118. The difference between 118 and -27 is 145. 118 - -27 = 118+27 = 145.
explanations.D: I think you may have found the difference between 27 and 118. But we need the difference between -27 and 118. It may help to think of the values on a number line. What is the gap between them? You could go from -27 to zero and then from zero to 118 to help break it down.
